facts.text: The occurrence took place at about 11-30 p.m. on November 10, 1955, at Muthupet, in front of the tea stall of Kannuswami.

anchor.surface_text: The occurrence which was the subject-matter of the charges against the two appellants took place at about 11-30 p.m. on November 10, 1955, at Muthupet, in front of the tea stall of Kannuswami, husband of Shrimati

facts.text: Kannuswami was murdered by the first appellant using an aruval on his chest, then later on head, neck and back.

anchor.surface_text: Kannuswami, husband of Shrimati Dhanabagyam-prosecution witness No. 1who will be referred to, in the companyrse of this judgment, as the first witness , and who is the principal witness for the prosecution, because, as will presently appear, the prosecution case and the companyvictions and sentences of the appellants depend entirely upon her testimony.

facts.text: The second appellant stood nearby while the first appellant inflicted the cutting injuries.

anchor.surface_text: According to the testimony of the first witness, it was the first appellant, the second accused  A-2 in therecord , who inflicted cutting injuries with the aruval. The second appellant, the first accused  A-1 inthe record , was standing nearby at the time the cutting injuries were inflicted.

facts.text: There were electric lights burning in the tea shop, a Panchayat Board light on the road, and a light on the pathway to the cinema-house.

anchor.surface_text: There were two electric lights burning in the tea shop, a Panchayat Board light burning on the road, as also a light burning on the pathway leading to the cinema-house.

facts.text: Shrimati Dhanabagyam (PW1), wife of Kannuswami, is the principal eyewitness.

anchor.surface_text: husband of Shrimati Dhanabagyam-prosecution witness No. 1who will be referred to, in the companyrse of this judgment, as the first witness , and who is the principal witness for the prosecution

facts.text: PW1 lodged the first information report (Exhibit P-1) at the police station after the incident.

anchor.surface_text: The wife of the deceased, finding her husband thus murdered, went and told Ganapathi-Prosecution Witness No. 4--who had a tea stall on the other side of the road, and informed him as to what had taken place. He asked her to lodge information of the occurrence at the Police Station.

facts.text: Sub-Inspector of Police recorded PW1's statement as FIR and held inquest.

anchor.surface_text: She then went to the Mathupet Police Station, but found it shut. She went to the house of the Sub-Inspector of Police, who took her to the Police Station, and recorded her statement as the first information report  Exhibit P. 1 .

facts.text: Court of Sessions, East Tanjore Division at Nagapattinam, delivered judgment on March 28, 1956 in S.C. No. 5 of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated July 25, 1956, of the Madras High Court in Criminal Appeals Nos. 247 248 of 1956 and Referred Trial No. 41 of 1956 arising out of the judgment and order dated March 28, 1956 of the Court of Sessions, East Tanjore Division at Nagapatam, in care S.C. No. 5 of 1956.

facts.text: Sessions Court sentenced first appellant to death under s.302 IPC for murder of Kannuswami.

anchor.surface_text: confirming the sentence of death passed by the Court of Sessions, East Tanjore Division, at Nagapattinam, under s. 302 of the Indian Penal Code, against appellant in Criminal Appeal No. 24 of 1957, for the murder of Kannuswami

facts.text: Sessions Court convicted second appellant under s.302 r/w s.109 IPC and sentenced to life imprisonment.

anchor.surface_text: and modifying the order of companyviction and sentence under s. 302, read with s. 109 of the Indian Penal Code, to one under s. 326, Indian Penal Code, and reducing the sentence of imprisonment for life to one for 5 years, in respect of the appellant in Criminal Appeal No. 25 of 1957.

facts.text: Madras High Court on July 25, 1956 confirmed death sentence for first appellant and modified second appellant's conviction to s.326 IPC with 5 years imprisonment.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated July 25, 1956, of the Madras High Court in Criminal Appeals Nos. 247 248 of 1956 and Referred Trial No. 41 of 1956 arising out of the judgment and order dated March 28, 1956

facts.text: Supreme Court heard appeals Nos. 24 and 25 of 1957 by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeals Nos. 24 and 25 of 1957. Appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated July 25, 1956, of the Madras High Court in Criminal Appeals Nos. 247 248 of 1956

facts.text: PW2 (Singaram) testified seeing Vadivelu cut Kannuswami and Chinniah standing by, but denied accused in dock were those persons.

anchor.surface_text: P.W. 2Singaram -testified to the occurrence and stated that he had seen Vadivelu Cut Kannuswami and Chinniah standing by the side of Vadivelu, a few feet away but he added that the accused persons were number those company- cerned with the crime though they bore the same names.

facts.text: PW3 (Shunmuga Thevar) turned hostile, denied telling police he saw accused assaulting.

anchor.surface_text: P.W. 3, one of the proprietors of the cinema-house, when examined in companyrt, admitted that he had been examined by the police two days after the occurrence, but stated that he did number tell the Police that he had seen the accused assaulting Kannuswami.

facts.text: PW4 (Ganapathi) stated PW1 told him Chinniah and Vadivelu cut her husband, but denied accused were those persons.

anchor.surface_text: Witness No. 4 for the Prosecution-Ganapathi-who ran a tea stall near the cinema-house, about 50 to 60 feet away from the tea stall of the deceased Kannuswami, stated in companyrt that the first witness came to him weeping and saying that Chinniah and Vadivelu Thevar had cut her husband, but added that the two accused in companyrt were number those persons.

facts.text: Convictions rest solely on testimony of PW1.

anchor.surface_text: The orders of companyviction and sentence, as passed by the companyrts below, as indicated above, rest solely on the testimony of the first witness.

facts.text: PW1's statement to committing magistrate (Exhibit D-2) had a recording error attributing cuts to accused 1 instead of 2.

anchor.surface_text: She has been cross- examined with reference to her statement  Exhibit D-2  recorded by the companymitting Magistrate, and she has categorically stated Accused 1 had numberweapon of any kind with him.

facts.text: Supreme Court accepted Sessions Judge's finding that Exhibit D-2 had a mistake in recording.

anchor.surface_text: We have looked into the whole -evidence of the first witness, as recorded by the companymitting Magistrate-not printed in the record, but supplied to us by the learned companynsel for the appellants-and in our opinion, there is numberdoubt that the learned Sessions Judge was companyrect

facts.text: Appellants' appeals in High Court did not raise discrepancy in PW1's statement.

anchor.surface_text: In neither of the Memoranda of Appeal, any ground has been taken that the first witness had materially companytradicted herself with reference to her previous statement in the companymittal companyrt.

facts.text: Kannuswami had past criminal history: transported for life for murder, later jailed twice for cut injuries.

anchor.surface_text: She admitted that he had been transported for life for having companymitted a murder and that after his release also, he had been sent to jail twice for having caused cut injuries to others.

facts.text: Supreme Court found PW1's testimony reliable and consistent.

anchor.surface_text: Her evidence, read as a whole, rings quite true, and we have numberhesitation in acting upon it.

facts.text: Medical evidence consistent with PW1's story of double attack.

anchor.surface_text: Her story of the double attack, first on the-front, and subsequently on the- back and side of the victim, is also companysistent with the medical evidence as deposed to by the Medical Officer-P.W. 8.

facts.text: Supreme Court upheld conviction of first appellant for murder under s.302 IPC and death sentence.

anchor.surface_text: We cannot accede to this line of argument. The first question which the companyrt has to companysider in a case like this, is whether the accused has been proved, to the satisfaction of the companyrt, to have companymitted the crime.

issues.text: Whether corroboration is required by law for the testimony of a single witness or only as a rule of prudence

anchor.surface_text: It is a sound rule in practice not to act on the uncorroborated evidence of a child, whether sworn or unsworn, but this is a rule of prudence and not of law.

issues.text: Whether Section 134 of the Indian Evidence Act requires a particular number of witnesses for proof of any fact

anchor.surface_text: Section 134 of the Indian Evidence Act has categorically laid it down that no particular number of witnesses shall in any case be required for the proof of any fact.

arguments.claim: Conviction and sentences should not be upheld because they rest solely on the testimony of the first witness which is not free from blemish due to discrepancy in Exhibit D-2 attributing cuts to accused 1 instead of 2
arguments.court_reasoning: Mistake in recording by committing Magistrate; consistent throughout deposition that accused 2 inflicted injuries; not challenged in lower courts

arguments.claim: First witness materially contradicted herself with reference to her previous statement in the committing court regarding who inflicted the injuries
arguments.court_reasoning: Recording defective, accused 1 written instead of 2; Sessions Judge correct; not raised in High Court appeals or leave petition

arguments.claim: PW3's testimony contradicts PW1 as PW3 denied seeing assault but PW1 said PW3 remonstrated

anchor.surface_text: The second ground of attack against the veracity of the first witness is that she had stated that Shanmugham Thevar- Prosecution Witness No. 3-had also seen the first appellant giving the deadly blows to her husband

arguments.court_reasoning: PW3's prior statement to police contradicts his court statement; both cannot be true; not strong enough to discredit PW1

arguments.claim: Not safe to convict on uncorroborated testimony of single witness in murder case as rule of prudence or law
arguments.court_reasoning: No legal requirement for corroboration except statute; rule of prudence only for child/accomplice; s.134 Evidence Act; quality over quantity; PW1 wholly reliable

arguments.claim: Corroboration required for single witness testimony citing Privy Council case (Mohamed Sugal Esa)
arguments.court_reasoning: Distinguished: child witness unsworn; rule of prudence not law; Indian Evidence Act no such provision

arguments.claim: Corroboration required citing Supreme Court case Vemireddy Satyanarayan Reddy
arguments.court_response: analogous to accomplice; peculiar circumstances; not general rule

arguments.claim: Court should not impose extreme penalty of death; lesser punishment suffices
arguments.court_reasoning: Cold-blooded murder; no extenuating circumstances; sentence independent of proof quality

arguments.claim: PW1 testimony reliable despite other witnesses turning hostile; consistent with FIR and medical evidence
No legal bar to convict on single credible witness; general rule courts can act on uncorroborated single witness
Corroboration not required except as prudence for child witness or accomplice
Section 134 Evidence Act: no particular number of witnesses required; evidence weighed not counted
Death sentence appropriate for first appellant as cold-blooded murder with no extenuating circumstances
High Court correctly modified second appellant's conviction to s.326 IPC and 5 years RI
Petition in High Court did not raise discrepancy ground, only interested/artificial testimony
arguments.court_reasoning: Supports rejection as not raised earlier

holdings.text: The recording of the first witness's statement in Exhibit D-2 by the committing Magistrate is defective, with 'accused 1' recorded in place of 'accused 2'; there is no material contradiction in her testimony.

anchor.surface_text: We have looked into the whole -evidence of the first witness, as recorded by the committing Magistrate-not printed in the record, but supplied to us by the learned counsel for the appellants-and in our opinion, there is nodoubt that the learned Sessions Judge was correct

holdings.reasoning_summary: Court examined full deposition; consistent attribution of injuries to accused 2 throughout; not challenged in lower courts or appeals.

holdings.text: The evidence of PW3 does not contradict PW1 sufficiently to discredit her, as PW3's statements at different stages cannot both be true.
holdings.reasoning_summary: PW3 turned hostile; prior police statement supports PW1; one of PW3's versions false, prefers PW1's reliable testimony.

holdings.text: The testimony of the first witness (PW1) is wholly reliable, consistent, and sufficient to prove the prosecution case beyond doubt.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Cross-examined severely; frank admissions; consistent with FIR, medical evidence; other witnesses unreliable/hostile.

holdings.text: As a general rule, a court can and may act on the testimony of a single witness though uncorroborated; one credible witness outweighs multiple indifferent ones.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Established proposition from authorities and Evidence Act; quality over quantity; applies to PW1.

holdings.text: Corroboration not required by law for single witness testimony unless insisted by statute; only rule of prudence for child witnesses, accomplices, or analogous cases.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes Privy Council (child unsworn), SC case (accomplice-like); no general rule for murder; PW1 not suspect category.

holdings.text: Section 134 of the Indian Evidence Act requires no particular number of witnesses for proof of any fact; evidence to be weighed, not counted.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation; legislative intent against plurality requirement; maxim of quality over quantity.

holdings.text: The appellants are proved guilty based on PW1's reliable testimony; first appellant guilty of murder under s.302 IPC.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Guilt proved to satisfaction; conviction follows; applies facts to s.302 via PW1.

holdings.text: Death sentence upheld for first appellant under s.302 IPC as appropriate for cold-blooded murder with no extenuating circumstances.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Sentence independent of proof; based on crime circumstances; double attack ensures death, no mitigation.

holdings.text: High Court's modification of second appellant's conviction to s.326 IPC and sentence to 5 years RI upheld.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Accepts High Court's reasons; standing by during assault warrants punishment under s.326.

precedents.citation: Mohamed Sugal Esa Mamasan Rer Alalah v. The, King 1

anchor.surface_text: Mohamed Sugal Esa Mamasan Rer Alalah v. The, King 1 . In that case, their Lordships looked for corroboration of the testimony of a single witness in a murder case.

precedents.case_name: Mohamed Sugal Esa Mamasan Rer Alalah v. The King
precedents.cited_proposition: It is a sound rule in practice not to act on the uncorroborated evidence of a child, whether sworn or unsworn, but this is a rule of prudence and not of law
precedents.cited_holding: Once there is admissible evidence a court can act upon it; corroboration, unless required by statute, goes only to the weight and value of the evidence.

precedents.citation: Vemireddy Satyanarayan Reddy and three others v. The State of Hyderabad 1 1956 S.C.R. 247

anchor.surface_text: Vemireddy Satyanarayan Reddy and three others v. The State of Hyderabad 1 1956 S.C.R. 247. was also relied upon in support of the contention that in a murder case the court insists on corroboration of the testimony of a single witness.

precedents.case_name: Vemireddy Satyanarayan Reddy v. State of Hyderabad
precedents.cited_proposition: Corroboration required for testimony of single witness analogous to accomplice in murder case
precedents.cited_holding: Though he was not an accomplice, we would still want corroboration on material particulars in this particular case, as he is the only witness to the crime and as it would be unsafe to hang four people on his sole testimony unless we feel convinced that he is speaking the truth.

justification_sets.label: Conviction on Single Witness Testimony support
Conviction on Single Witness Testimony support
Conviction on Single Witness Testimony support

anchor.surface_text: We cannot accede to this line of argument. The first question which the court has to consider in a case like this, is whether the accused has been proved, to the satisfaction of the court, to have committed the crime. If the court is convinced about the truth of the prosecution story, conviction has to follow. The question of sentence has to be determined, not with reference to the volume or character of the evidence adduced by the prosecution in support of the prosecution case, but with reference to the fact whether there are any extenuating circumstances which can be said to mitigate the enormity of the crime.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeals dismissed; death sentence under s.302 IPC confirmed against first appellant; conviction and 5 years RI sentence under s.326 IPC confirmed against second appellant

We cannot accede to this line of argument. The first question which the court has to consider in a case like this, is whether the accused has been proved, to the satisfaction of the court, to have committed the crime. If the court is convinced about the truth of the prosecution story, conviction has to follow. The question of sentence has to be determined, not with reference to the volume or character of the evidence adduced by the prosecution in support of the prosecution case, but with reference to the fact whether there are any extenuating circumstances which can be said to mitigate the enormity of the crime.

anchor.surface_text: We cannot accede to this line of argument. The first question which the court has to consider in a case like this, is whether the accused has been proved, to the satisfaction of the court, to have committed the crime. If the court is convinced about the truth of the prosecution story, conviction has to follow. The question of sentence has to be determined, not with reference to the volume or character of the evidence adduced by the prosecution in support of the prosecution case, but with reference to the fact whether there are any extenuating circumstances which can be said to mitigate the enormity of the crime.
